title: 🛠 Private Infra Ready: Copilot Coding Agent + Your Self-Hosted Runners (Public Preview)
content: Copilot coding agent can now run its development environment on your own infrastructure using self-hosted GitHub Actions runners managed by Actions Runner Controller (ARC). That means agent tasks can reach internal packages, private build tooling, or on-prem services that aren’t exposed to the public internet—while still remaining ephemeral, isolated, and automated. 🤖 What This Unlocks Use internal dependency registries or artifact stores (npm, Maven, PyPI mirrors, etc.). Run tests against services only reachable inside your network. Apply existing compliance / observability layers already baked into your runner fleet. Keep Copilot’s environment disposable—every task starts clean, ends clean. 🧩 How It Works (Recap) Copilot coding agent executes tasks in a GitHub Actions-powered environment. By default we provision hosted runners. Now you can override the environment via copilot-setup-steps.yml and target an ARC scale set. 🔧 Setup Steps Deploy ARC and create a scale set: Quickstart: https://docs.github.com/actions/tutorials/use-actions-runner-controller/quickstart Edit copilot-setup-steps.yml in the repository (or org standard) to point to your scale set via runs-on:. Commit & delegate a task to Copilot coding agent—your agent now boots on your infra. jobs: copilot-setup-steps: runs-on: arc-scale-set-name steps: uses: actions/checkout@v4 Add any setup your internal environment needs name: Install private deps run: npm ci 🛡️ Security & Isolation Notes Each task still uses an ephemeral workspace—no state leakage between tasks. Your existing runner-level security policies (network ACLs, scanning, logging) apply automatically. Keep secrets management consistent with other ARC-based workflows. ✅ Recommended First Uses Internal SDK refactors Dependency upgrades needing private registry access Integration tests hitting staging APIs behind a firewall Legacy monorepo tasks with custom internal toolchains 📎 Tips Standardize a base copilot-setup-steps.yml template at the org level for consistency. Include lightweight caching if internal dependency retrieval is slow. Pair with CodeQL & secret scanning already built into coding agent for layered protection. 📘 Learn More Customizing agent environment ARC quickstart 💬 Feedback Let us know what’s missing—metrics visibility? multi-arch scale sets? runner health telemetry surfaced in the agent summary? Drop ideas in comments below: Bring Copilot to where your code actually lives. 🔐

title: Pick the repository and base branch when assigning issues to Copilot
content: We're bringing you a range of additional options for assigning Copilot to issues as part of this public preview. When assigning an issue to Copilot coding agent, you can now choose which repository Copilot should work in, pick a starting branch, and provide additional instructions to give it more context. CCA.issue.assign.mp4 Here’s what’s new: Start Copilot assignment in one click: Assign tasks directly to Copilot with the new Assign to Copilot button. This feature makes it easier and faster to start a Copilot assignment with a single click. Pick the target repository: Choose any repository you have access to, even if your issues and code don't live in the same place. Now you can work with Copilot across repositories, so it's easy to start assignments from issues no matter where your code is stored. Pick a starting branch: Choose which branch Copilot should start from. Whether you want Copilot to work off a feature branch, a bug fix branch, or any other starting point, you now have the flexibility to direct Copilot’s work to exactly where you want it. Add additional instructions: Give Copilot more context with optional instructions. You can provide specific guidance, requirements, or extra details to help Copilot understand exactly what you want to accomplish. This makes assignments more precise and helps Copilot deliver results that match your needs. For more details, check out our documentation on assigning Copilot to an issue. 👇 Want to share feedback on this public preview or join the conversation? Please comment below! title: Custom agents for GitHub Copilot
content: Custom agents for GitHub Copilot make it easy for users and organizations to specialize their Copilot coding agent (CCA) through simple, file-based configurations. By adding a configuration file under .github/agents in a repository or in the {org}/.github repository, you can define agent personas that capture your team’s workflows, conventions, and unique needs. These agents can be further tailored with prompts, tool selections, and Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to optimize for specific use cases. Anyone using GitHub Copilot can define and use custom agents, whether you’re an individual developer, part of a team, or managing an organization. Custom agents work across Copilot coding agent in github.com, the Copilot CLI, and will be coming to a future release of Visual Studio Code. Key benefits Define agent specializations that act like focused teammates, using prompts and tool selections unique to your workflow. Add organization-specific or team-specific agents by placing configuration files in a known location in your repository or organization settings. Refine agent behaviors beyond standard Copilot instructions, making it easier to enforce coding conventions, compliance, or custom automations. Enable agents to use custom tools and MCP servers, giving you fine-grained control over how tasks are completed. Get started quickly by adding a simple markdown file. There’s no need for a separate installation or complex setup. Examples Imagine a frontend engineer subagent that enforces team conventions for React or Vue, or an agent that uses a custom MCP to automate additional tasks with the GitHub CLI. With custom agents, you can define these behaviors in a central file, making them easily accessible and maintainable. Not sure where to begin? Some of our awesome partners have created custom agents to help you improve your workflow. You can find those and more sample agents at @github/awesome-copilot. 🌟Leave a comment! Learn more by reading our docs on custom agents and join the discussion by leaving feedback in the comments below!

From enterprise-grade control to seamless delegation in more IDEs, to smarter, safer automated contributions—Copilot just got a lot more powerful. 🛡️ Enterprise AI controls & the Agent Control Plane (public preview) Enterprise Cloud admins now have a dedicated home to govern AI systems: Unified “AI controls” view for policies, configuration, and oversight. title: Manage Copilot and users via Enterprise Teams in public preview
content: 🆕 GitHub Enterprise Cloud now offers Enterprise Teams in public preview, streamlining enterprise user and Copilot license management experiences for businesses. Enterprise owners can now: Add users directly to the enterprise without requiring organization access. These unaffiliated users do not consume a license by default. Create and manage groups of users in the enterprise account through Enterprise Teams. Enterprise accounts with Enterprise Managed Users can synchronize groups of users from their identity provider to Enterprise Teams via SCIM. Manage Copilot Business licenses for individuals or entire enterprise teams through the enterprise-level Copilot licensing page. What Enterprise Teams enable ❓ In the coming months, enterprise owners will also be able to use enterprise teams to: Assign an enterprise role. Assign it to a number of organizations within that enterprise, granting organization membership. Empower organization and repository owners to assign roles to teams within their scope. Unaffiliated users (non-EMU enterprises) 👀 For enterprises that do not use enterprise-managed users (EMU), enterprise owners can now invite unaffiliated users to their enterprise. These users will not have access to organizations or licenses by default, but can later be assigned to an enterprise team, an organization, or Copilot Business license. If a user is removed from all organizations, they will remain in the enterprise as an unaffiliated user unless the remove from enterprise action is taken. Since users may not be automatically removed from your enterprise, we recommend reviewing your offboarding process to ensure it accounts for this change. Copilot Business licensing updates 💼 Along with enterprise teams and unaffiliated users now being available to all enterprises, updates have been made to Copilot Business licensing. Enterprise owners can use a dedicated Copilot Business licensing page to assign users and enterprise teams. These updates provide more flexible and scalable license management for enterprises, including the ability to assign Copilot Business to users without also requiring a GitHub Enterprise Cloud license. Join us in the comments below to share your feedback and ask questions. 👇 Learn more To learn more, check out our documentation on Enterprise Teams, unaffiliated users, and Copilot Business licensing. If you have feedback about these new features, join us on this discussion. ⚠️ Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

title: Managing Copilot Business in enterprise is now generally available
content: Enterprise owners with GitHub Enterprise Cloud can assign Copilot Business licenses inside an enterprise account independent of granting any organizational access. This experience provides a flexible, more scalable Copilot Business licensing model to enterprises without requiring a GitHub Enterprise Cloud license per user. To assign Copilot Business licenses through an enterprise account, your users will need to already exist in the enterprise, whether as a preexisting organization member or as an unaffiliated user. Whether you assign to the user directly or through an enterprise team, enterprise owners can use the dedicated Copilot Business licensing page to assign these licenses. If a user is assigned both through an organization and through the enterprise directly, they will only consume one license, and they will have access to the highest Copilot license assigned to them. The new dedicated licensing page provides enterprise owners with: An overview of current Copilot license consumption in the enterprise. A centralized place to enable Copilot across the enterprise and its organizations. The ability to manage Copilot Business direct assignments across users and enterprise teams. For new enterprises who start with our GitHub trial, the experience has been updated to allow enterprise owners to try out this new licensing experience on day one. Enterprise owners can convert their trial with only the Copilot Business licenses assigned at the enterprise license and add in GitHub Enterprise Cloud licenses later as needed. To learn more, read our documentation on Copilot Business licensing, Enterprise Teams, and unaffiliated users. 🌟Leave a comment! Join the discussion and leave feedback in the comments below!

title: Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API in public preview
content: The AI era of software development isn’t about are teams using AI, but rather how well are they using it? The GitHub Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API, now in public preview for GitHub Enterprise customers using Copilot, helps you answer that question with data. You can now see how Copilot adoption and engagement in the IDE varies across both your enterprise and your users to understand who’s using it, where, and how. What’s included in the public preview The Copilot usage metrics dashboard gives enterprise administrators and billing managers direct visibility into Copilot usage and adoption under the Insights tab. The dashboard provides an aggregated enterprise view, while the NDJSON download or API offer user-level granularity for deeper analysis. In this public preview, you’ll find metrics including: Daily and weekly active users across GitHub Copilot IDE modes, including agent mode. Agent adoption across your user base. Lines of code added and deleted across all IDE modes. Language and model usage patterns across IDEs. These metrics help you understand: Overall usage and adoption: Review indicators like weekly usage provide a broad view of Copilot adoption across your enterprise. Specific model, feature, and language usage: See which AI models and programming languages are most utilized by your teams, highlighting areas for even greater value. Agent adoption percentage: Track how many developers are using Copilot for advanced tasks like refactoring, debugging, and complex problem solving. High agent adoption signals a shift toward truly transformative coding. Together, these are foundational metrics showing who’s adopting Copilot, how consistently, and what that usage looks like across your enterprise. How to enable Copilot usage metrics in your enterprise By default, Copilot usage metrics are disabled unless your enterprise participated in the private preview, in which case they remain enabled. Enterprise admins can enable them as follows: Navigate to your AI Controls tab on github.com. Select Copilot in the left sidebar. Scroll down to the "Metrics" section where you’ll see Copilot usage metrics. Change the Copilot usage metrics policy setting to Enabled. This will enable the Copilot usage metrics dashboard and API for your enterprise, allowing enterprise administrators and billing managers to view usage and adoption data. Once enabled, you can access the Copilot usage metrics dashboard directly from the Insights tab at the enterprise level or through the Enterprise and user-level API. Learn more View the Copilot usage metrics dashboard documentation. Explore the Copilot usage metrics API. Join us in the comments below to share your feedback and ask questions. Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

title: Copilot Generates Commit Messages on .com [GA]
content: GitHub Copilot now offers contextual commit message suggestions for file changes made on github.com—making lightweight documentation an effortless, integrated part of every commit. This feature was previously in public preview and is now generally available to all Copilot users. 🎉 When enabled, Copilot automatically suggests a concise, relevance‑focused summary of the changes you made through the file editor on github.com. Deleting a file continues to use the existing default: Delete <filename> Adding a new file with no contents continues to use the existing default: Add <filename> Enabling Copilot-generated commit messages Copilot-generated commit messages are available to users on all GitHub Copilot plans (including Free, Pro/Pro+, Business, and Enterprise). Individuals: You can opt out at any time via the “Copilot‑generated commit messages” toggle in your Copilot settings. Enterprises & organizations (including GitHub Enterprise Cloud with data residency): Administrators can opt in through enterprise administrator settings. Enterprises already opted into public preview features are automatically enabled for Copilot-generated commit messages. Commit metadata rulesets: If your enterprise has rulesets enforcing commit metadata, you will still see a default commit message for commits made in organization‑related repositories where those restrictions apply. Your Feedback Matters Join us in the comments below to share feedback, ask questions, or suggest improvements. Start using Copilot-generated commit messages today and keep your commit history clean, consistent, and informative—without the extra friction.

title: Introducing Copilot Spaces: A new way to work with context ✨
content: Copilot Spaces is a new feature within GitHub Copilot. You can organize and centralize relevant content—like code, docs, files, and (soon) issues—into “Spaces” that ground Copilot’s responses in the right context for a specific task. Key Features ✨ Create a space Organize code, docs, files, and other project context into a space. Add custom instructions to help guide responses. We’ve made some adjustments to how Copilot works with context in Spaces, so context groundedness should be very high. Context is always based on the latest state of your main branch. Chat with a space Ask Copilot questions grounded in the context of your Space for more accurate and relevant answers. Share it with teammates You can share spaces with other members of your organization. Some of our favorite use cases ⭐ Answering questions about code: Chris Westra is an engineer on the Spaces team. He grouped all of the code associated with Spaces and added video transcripts from a recorded Spaces session. We use this Space to answer questions about how Spaces works under-the-hood (very meta). 🙂 Standardizing coding standards and best practices: Rahul Zhade works on a team that advises engineers on secure coding practices. He often answers the same questions over-and-over again in Slack, so he set up a Space. It contains the documentation for our standard auth model, how to do cryptography as well as instructions on how to go through the security review process. Writing SQL/KQL queries: Kelly Henckel is a product manager who is very good at writing SQL and KQL queries. She’s created spaces designed to help people self-service writing data queries and creating dashboards. These helpers contain the code for our telemetry schemas as well as example queries. Updating documentation: Holly Kassel is a product manager working on billing and licensing. She’s been updating GitHub’s documentation to be more user-friendly based on questions arriving through our customer support channels and discussion posts. She creates spaces for each new batch of documentation which needs to be updated, links the existing code and documentation hosted in GitHub, and adds instructions and frequently asked questions as context. The space generates updated versions of the documentation which can be easily copied into our docs repo. And more We’ve also been having fun with them. Hubbers created a personal finance space for answering questions about vesting and other benefits, an offsite space for consolidating travel information, and a wombat Space for, uh, wombats? Anyways… Please share feedback with us 🤝 This is an early preview, so we appreciate your feedback. Give spaces a try and let us know what you think either in this discussion post or through the inline feedback button. Go to Spaces 🚀 See the detailed changelog post. Learn more about spaces in our documentation on Copilot Spaces.

title: Anthropic’s Claude Haiku 4.5 is in public preview for GitHub Copilot

title: Copilot generated commit messages on github.com is in public preview
content: GitHub Copilot now offers contextual commit message suggestions for github.com file changes, making documentation an effortless part of your workflow. With this enhancement, Copilot automatically suggests a concise summary of changes made through the file editor on github.com. Deleting a file continues to use the existing default: Delete <filename> Adding a new file without any contents continues to use the existing default: Add <filename> commitmessagedemo2.mp4 Availability and usage Copilot commit message generation is available to all public preview enabled paid Copilot subscribers. It does not consume usage quota. Enabling the feature for organizations and enterprises Organizations and enterprises can enable this and other features in public preview by selecting Opt in to preview features in the Copilot in github.com setting. If your Enterprise has rulesets for commit metadata enabled, you will still see a default commit message in commits made in organization-related files. This feature is also available in GitHub Enterprise Cloud with data residency. Share your feedback ➡️ Give us feedback on this feature or let us know what you think in the comments below!

title: Instant semantic code search indexing for GitHub Copilot
content: GitHub Copilot now features Instant semantic code search indexing! This dramatically reduces indexing time from approximately 5 minutes to just a few seconds (maximum 60 seconds in some cases). What this means for you Now when you open a repository, Copilot can almost immediately provide contextually-aware assistance specific to your codebase. Semantic Code Search, one of GitHub Copilot's most powerful capabilities, enables Copilot to: Provide responses specific to your codebase's architecture and patterns. Reference existing functions, classes, and implementations in your repo. Suggest code that aligns with your project's style and conventions. Answer questions about your codebase with accurate, context-aware information. How to use it The indexing process starts automatically when you open GitHub Copilot Chat on github.com. VS Code users with the GitHub Copilot extension can manually trigger indexing through the Copilot UI when needed. Availability This feature is now available to all GitHub Copilot users across all tiers, including the free tier, with no limits on how many repositories can be indexed. More information For detailed information about repository indexing, check out our documentation. What do you think about this improvement? Have you noticed a difference in your workflow? Let us know in the comments below!

title: Copilot coding agent is now generally available! 🚀
content: Discussion updated: 09-25-2025 Copilot coding agent, our asynchronous, autonomous developer agent, is now generally available for all paid Copilot subscribers. Delegate a task to Copilot, and Copilot will open a draft pull request and work in the background in its own development environment. It does this through the power of GitHub Actions. Once Copilot is done, it will request a review from you, and you can ask Copilot to make changes by leaving comments on the pull request. GHPadawanWIP01.mp4 Copilot coding agent can complete a wide range of software development tasks including: Implementing new features Fixing bugs Addressing technical debt Improving test coverage Updating documentation There are many ways to hand tasks to Copilot, including assigning it an issue, using the agents panel accessible on every page on GitHub, or using the Delegate to coding agent button in Visual Studio Code. To learn more about Copilot coding agent, head to our documentation. If you're a Copilot Business or Copilot Enterprise subscriber, an administrator will have to enable Copilot coding agent from the "Policies" page before you can use it. title: Scale Institutional Knowledge with GitHub Copilot Spaces and Agents
content: TL;DR Scattered tribal knowledge throttles onboarding, cross-team work, and agent outcomes. Copilot pulls trusted context into the flow of work so everyone ships faster. Pair Copilot Spaces, Coding Agent, Agent Mode, and Copilot Code Review to hit the big four wins: faster time-to-first-PR, fewer interrupts to senior engineers, consistent patterns, and stronger autonomous results. Below you’ll find an urgency hook, discovery prompts, a pilot plan, objection handling, and a resource stack that keeps knowledge current in IDEs, PRs, and automated workflows. Why this matters The average large U.S. business loses $47M every year to inefficient knowledge sharing; workers burn ~5.3 hours a week searching for answers or recreating past work.[^1][^2] A 1,000-person knowledge workforce can waste $2.5–$3.5M annually hunting for non-existent or hard-to-find info—plus ~$15M in opportunity cost.[^3] Developers spend ~17 hours/week on maintenance and ~4 hours/week on “bad code,” implying ~$85B in global productivity drag.[^4] Better knowledge sharing boosts knowledge-worker productivity by 20–25%.[^5] Use these proof points to frame a 30–90 day pilot with execs who care about onboarding speed, duplicate work, and senior focus time. Who to target Customers with onboarding friction, siloed standards, or inconsistent practices—anywhere “How do I…?” questions slow delivery. Ideal customer profile: New devs take 1–3 months to land their first meaningful PRs; leadership cites long waits for the first three PRs.[^6] Know-how sits in experts’ heads or outdated wikis; “Where’s the doc?” pings flood Slack/Teams. Standards vary by squad, resulting in duplicated implementations and frequent “please follow the guidelines” PR nudges. Senior ICs lose deep-work hours answering basic Q&A. Signals to look for: No clear single source of truth for architecture, APIs, runbooks, or conventions. High time-to-first-PR for new hires; constant interrupts to senior engineers. Evidence of reinvented solutions, missed standards, or quality regressions in PRs. Talk track: discovery + business framing Start by uncovering where knowledge breaks today: “What questions do new developers ask repeatedly?” “Where do developers go for onboarding or when they’re stuck?” “Which standards do teams most often miss, rediscover, or debate?” “How do you provide trusted, customized knowledge to AI tools or agents today?” “How do you keep documentation from going stale?” Reframe the answers in business terms: Faster onboarding → reduce time-to-first-PR by giving new hires a Space that “knows your systems.” Fewer interrupts → senior engineers regain focus time as common questions resolve inside the IDE or chat. Consistency and quality → everyone follows the same vetted examples, cutting defects and rework. Agent-ready → via MCP, the same vetted context powers internal tools and autonomous agents. Three ways Copilot scales institutional knowledge Embedded best practices in the flow of work Copilot completions, chat answers, and code review comments reflect org-wide standards, repo idioms, and golden-path snippets. New contributors code like they’ve already internalized the expert playbook. Reduced dependency on gatekeepers Spaces curate live code, runbooks, standards, and how-tos. Copilot surfaces context proactively so developers don’t need to “tap the shoulder” of a veteran teammate. Faster onboarding and continuous knowledge transfer Domain language, framework nuances, and migration recipes appear where work happens—IDE, PRs, agent prompts—so knowledge sharing is real time, not quarterly training. Step-by-step pilot plan (30–90 days) Phase What to do Outcome Identify the opportunity Baseline time-to-first-PR for recent hires, volume of repeated Q&A, duplicated work examples; tie the pain to delayed features, lost senior capacity, or quality hits. Clear urgency + ROI hypothesis. Introduce Copilot Spaces Stand up a Space for one flagship product; attach live repos, key docs, concise standards/how-tos. Run a hands-on demo answering real questions with linked sources. Optionally show how an internal agent would query the Space via MCP. Stakeholders see trusted answers in context. Define success Set a concrete goal (e.g., cut TTFPR by 20% in 60–90 days, halve senior interrupts). Document the owner and success plan. Shared pilot scorecard. Track usage and impact Monitor Space analytics (queries/day, unique users, top topics). Capture user quotes. Measure outcome deltas vs. baseline: onboarding speed, repeat questions, standard violations. Evidence that knowledge flows improved. Prove business outcomes Translate results for execs: regained senior capacity, faster delivery, improved consistency. Recommend scaling to additional domains, onboarding flows, and agent workflows. Expansion path + budget request. Example flow summary Ask: Run a 30–90 day pilot on one critical service to quantify impact. Week 0: Enable Copilot Spaces; capture baseline metrics (onboarding, Q&A load). Weeks 1–4+: Team uses Space; you track usage and outcomes; collect anecdotes. Readout: Show faster onboarding, fewer interrupts, better consistency; propose scale-out. Be ready for common objections “We already have a wiki.” → Wikis go stale. Spaces ties live code and docs to AI answers inside the dev workflow, with citations to original sources.[^5] “Can we trust the answers?” → Responses are grounded in your repos/docs; you curate sources and visibility. “Is this secure?” → Data stays in your GitHub tenancy; access respects repo governance and branch protection. “Is setup heavy?” → Connect key repos/docs in minutes; Spaces stay up to date automatically as code changes. Keep knowledge fresh Treat Spaces and .github/copilot-instructions.md as living assets—schedule monthly reviews. Pin authoritative docs and retire stale references so Copilot’s context remains trustworthy. Capture success stories: when Copilot resolves a question or an agent completes a task, feed the insights back into your instructions. Pair with Copilot Code Review to reinforce conventions at PR time and catch drift early. title: 🚀 Now available: Copilot Spaces — A new way to work with context
content: Ever wish Copilot understood your project as well as your teammates do? Now it can. With Copilot Spaces, you can bring together the context Copilot needs (e.g. files, pull requests, issues, repos) into "Spaces". The result? Copilot gives you responses that are grounded in the right context for a specific task. Create a space Organize code, files, pull requests, issues and other project context into a space. Add custom instructions to help guide responses. We’ve made some adjustments to how Copilot works with context in Spaces, so context groundedness should be very high. Context is always based on the latest state of your main branch. Files and repositories added to a space are always kept up to date as they change, making Copilot an evergreen expert in your project. Chat with a space Ask Copilot questions grounded in the context of your Space for more accurate and relevant answers. Share it with teammates You can share spaces with other members of your organization. Spaces in the IDE Access your Space context directly from supported IDEs through the remote GitHub MCP Server. 📂 Do more with Spaces and use it to: Generate code Share knowledge Plan projects Some of our favorite use cases ⭐ Answering questions about code: Chris Westra is an engineer on the Spaces team. He grouped all of the code associated with Spaces and added video transcripts from a recorded Spaces session. We use this Space to answer questions about how Spaces works under-the-hood (very meta). 🙂 Standardizing coding standards and best practices: Rahul Zhade works on a team that advises engineers on secure coding practices. He often answers the same questions over-and-over again in Slack, so he set up a Space. It contains the documentation for our standard auth model, how to do cryptography as well as instructions on how to go through the security review process. Writing SQL/KQL queries: Kelly Henckel is a product manager who is very good at writing SQL and KQL queries. She’s created spaces designed to help people self-service writing data queries and creating dashboards. These helpers contain the code for our telemetry schemas as well as example queries. Updating documentation: Holly Kassel is a product manager working on billing and licensing. She’s been updating GitHub’s documentation to be more user-friendly based on questions arriving through our customer support channels and discussion posts. She creates spaces for each new batch of documentation which needs to be updated, links the existing code and documentation hosted in GitHub, and adds instructions and frequently asked questions as context. The space generates updated versions of the documentation which can be easily copied into our docs repo. Please share feedback with us 🤝 We appreciate your feedback. Give Spaces a try and let us know what you think either in this discussion post or through the inline feedback button. 🚀 Try Spaces now Learn more about Spaces: Changelog Documentation Microsoft Learn module - Introduction to Spaces GitHub Skills exercise

title: Speed up your Issue Creation with Copilot: Feedback
content: To help you create higher quality issues with greater ease, you can now create issues by chatting with Copilot. This experience is currently in public preview. Key Features Prompt to create an Issue: Create an issue by prompting Copilot. Copilot will transform your prompt into a fully created issue. Simply review and refine it before clicking create. Start with an image: Create an issue starting with an image. Copilot uploads the issue to the image. Review template guidance: View Copilot’s suggested templates based on your prompt. Make changes and Copilot will reformat the issue. Still to come... As this experience is in public preview, you may run into some bugs and missing features (let us know when you do). Some of areas we are working on include: Multi Issue Creation: Creating multiple issues with greater ease, rather than needing to click the Create button for each individual issue that Copilot drafts. Sub Issues: Nesting sub issues into parent issues. Updating Issues: Leveraging Copilot to update existing issues. Try it out To get started, go to https://github.com/copilot and try a prompt like … Create me an issue for.. Create me a bug for .. Feedback We want to hear from you! Post your comments, questions, likes, and dislikes below.

title: Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for GitHub Copilot
content: Claude Sonnet 4.5, Anthropic’s most advanced model for coding and real-world agents, is now rolling out in GitHub Copilot to Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. From our early testing, the model brings major upgrades in tool orchestration, context editing, and domain-specific capabilities. A_4.5.mov Availability in GitHub Copilot Copilot Chat Claude Sonnet 4.5 will be available for Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. You’ll be able to select the model in the Copilot Chat model picker from: Visual Studio Code in chat, ask, edit, and agent mode. github.com. GitHub Mobile in iOS and Android. Once enabled, users in that organization will have Claude Sonnet 4.5 available in the Copilot Chat model picker and Copilot CLI. Copilot Free, Pro, and Pro+ users may also bring their own key in Visual Studio Code by selecting Manage Models from the picker, choosing Anthropic, and entering their API key when prompted.
